abstract.t: As the IETF continues to produce and standardize different Operations, Administration, and Maintenance (OAM) protocols and technologies, various qualifiers and modifiers are prepended to the OAM acronym. While, at first glance, the most used appear to be well understood, experience has shown repeatedly that there is aliasing of terms (i.e., the same qualifier is interpreted to have different specific meaning.) This is notorious with the qualifiers "in-band" and "out-of-band", given that those are extrapolations from radio lexicon into communication networks.
This document explains the frequently-encountered problem, and lays out guideliens for use of qualifying terms when characteriging OAM.

section.title: Introduction
section.t: It is not uncoming for historical and popular terms to have fundamental nuances in how they are interpreted or understood. This was for example the case with the acronym "OAM", and provided guidelines for its use as well as definitions of its consitutive parts.

Experience shows that trying to characterize or qualify "OAM" often encounters similar problems. Specifically, with the adjective phrases "in-band" and "out-of-band". This document explains the root of the problem and proposes an unambiguous characterization.

section.title: Aliasing of In-Band and Out-of-Band
section.t: Historically, the terms "in-band" and "out-of-band" appear (likely, citation?) in radio communications, where there actually was a "Band" (i.e., a "Channel" of "Frequency".)

While those terms, useful in their simplicity, continued to be broadly used to mean "within something" and "outside said soomething", a challenge is presented when IP communications does not have a "band" per se, and in fact has multiple "somethings" that an OAM can go within or outside. A frequently encountered case is in-band to mean either in-packet or in-path.

The guideline on this document is to, first, attempt to avoid the terms "*-band" and instead find finer-granulary descriptive terms, as for example.
OAM in relationship to a path.
The OAM protocol follow the exact same path as the observed data traffic. This was sometimes refered to as "in-band".
The OAM protocol does not follow the same path as the observed data traffic. This was sometimes refered to as "out-of-band".
gives an example of "Path-Congruent OAM", and further describes the OAM Packets "share their fate with data packets."
OAM in relationship to a node.
The OAM protocol traverses through a node. This was sometimes refered to as "in-band".
The OAM protocol does not traverse through a node. This was sometimes refered to as "out-of-band".
OAM in relationship to a user data packet.
The OAM protocol is carried as part of data traffic. This was sometimes refered to as "in-band".
The OAM protocol has its own OAM packets, separated from data traffic. This was sometimes refered to as "out-of-band".
In Situ OAM is an example of "In-Packet OAM", given that it 'records OAM information within the packet while the packet traverses a particular network domain. The term "in situ" refers to the fact that the OAM data is added to the data packets rather than being sent within packets specifically dedicated to OAM.'
OAM in relationship to the treatment of user data packets, as for example QoS treatment.
The OAM packets receive the same QoS treatment as user data packets. This was sometimes refered to as "in-band".
The OAM packets receive different QoS treatment as user data packets. This was sometimes refered to as "out-of-band".
OAM in relationship to multiple criteria. For example, in relationship to both topological congruence and packet treatment. One such examples is .

section.title: Historical Uses
section.t: There are many examples of "in-band OAM" and "out-of-band OAM" in published documents. While interpreting those, it is important to understand the semantics of what is "band" a proxy for, and to be more explicit when those documents are updated.

For example, uses *-band to refer to the packets "as in-band traffic with the PW's data, or out-of-band", and "in-band (i.e., following the same data-plane faith as PW data)". Hence, the inexisting "band" would refer to the "Pseudowire data".

section.title: Active, Passive, and Hybrid OAM
section.t:
Even though does not include the specific terms Active, Passive, and Hybrid as modifiers of OAM, the following terms are generally used and well understood:
Depends on dedicated instrumentation OAM packet.
Depends *solely* on the observation of one or more existing data packet streams, and does not use dedicated OAM packets.
Has two definitions:
Uses either a combination of Active OAM and Passive OAM. Uses instrumentation or modification of data packets themselves.
Unfortunately, also describes "passive methods" as "out of band", adding to the confusion. This document recommends removing that additional qualification.

section.title: Use of OAM-Modifying Acronyms
section.t: It is not surprising to see how also several proposed and used acronyms alias. For example, is does the "I" in "IOAM" stand for in-band, in situ, or something else? Is the "O" in "OOAM" for overlay, for out-of-band, or something else? In light of the potential and experienced confusion caused by OAM extended characterization and acronyms this document's position is to simply avoid using them.

section.title: Security Considerations
section.t: Security is improved when the terms used and their definitions are unambiguous.
